[Zotero](https://www.zotero.org/) is a free, easy-to-use tool to help you collect, organize, annotate, cite, and share research.

## Integration with other plugins and tools

-   You can use NotionHQ and the Notero plugin to organise papers in a database and store detailes notes (see an [example template](https://dust-bovid-04d.notion.site/ba1bc5022a4d469abd2ea559e80bc56b?v=a953e6bf2a3449e9ab3083154ce2b238)).

-   [ZotFile](http://zotfile.com/) is a Zotero plugin to manage your attachments.

-   You can import BibTex files from Zotero in your [ORCID profile](https://orcid.org/) (an ORCID is a persistent identifier for researchers, where you can manage your research outputs yourself):

    ![](images/image-170768552.png){fig-alt="Screenshot of the ORCID webpage where you can add works via the Import BibTex option" width="454"}

## **More information**

-   [How do I import a Mendeley library into Zotero?](https://www.zotero.org/support/kb/mendeley_import)
    -   Ensure that you tell Mendeley desktop to sync attached files for your \*entire\* library **before** importing to Zotero. You can do this by clicking the "Edit Settings" button by "All Documents" in the main desktop window, and clicking "Synchronize attached files".
-   [Installing the Zotero Word Processor Plugins](https://www.zotero.org/support/word_processor_plugin_installation)
-   [How to Organize Literature and Notes in Zotero](https://calc.hypotheses.org/5692)
